name: Congress
title: Lula's balancing act: Cop30 Amazon summit juggles climate and social priorities
description:
Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, has welcomed world leaders to Belém for the first climate summit in the Amazon, where conservationists hope he can be a champion for the rainforest and its people.
Forest clearance in the Brazilian Amazon has fallen by 50% over the full three years of Lula’s third term in office.
This is largely thanks to Lula’s environment minister, Marina Silva, who has applied robust measures to counter land invasions, illegal logging and wildcat mining.
This was very much in keeping with one of Brazil’s declared objectives in the summit: to make social protection a foundation of resilience.
“Cop30 is a place for us to say that Brazil will do its part, eliminating deforestation.
text:
Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, has welcomed world leaders to Belém for the first climate summit in the Amazon, where conservationists hope he can be a champion for the rainforest and its people.

But with a divided administration, a hostile Congress and 20th-century developmentalist instincts, this global figurehead of the centre left has a balancing act to perform in advocating protection of nature and a reduction of emissions.

At the opening of the summit on Thursday, he said his priority was social development, but humanity had to make an energy transition and halt the loss of forests.

He said: “I am convinced that despite our difficulties and contradictions, we need roadmaps to – in a fair and planned way – reverse deforestation, overcome dependence on fossil fuels and mobilise the resources necessary for these objectives.”

Those difficulties and contradictions have been starkly apparent in recent months, in which the government has announced impressive progress in reducing deforestation, while also pushing forward a number of projects that would open up the Amazon to extractivism.

First, the good news. Forest clearance in the Brazilian Amazon has fallen by 50% over the full three years of Lula’s third term in office. The latest annual government figures show the smallest area of clearance in 11 years. This is largely thanks to Lula’s environment minister, Marina Silva, who has applied robust measures to counter land invasions, illegal logging and wildcat mining.

As a result, the Climate Observatory estimates Brazil’s emissions – which are mainly determined by the health of its forests – have fallen by 16.7%, likely to be the steepest fall of any of the G20 economies.

These gains were front and centre as Lula pitched for more nations to sign up to Brazil’s flagship initiative at Cop30: the Tropical Forest Forever Facility, which aims to raise $125bn (£95bn) for the protection of standing forests. So far, the initiative has raised about $5.5bn, with investments of $3bn from Norway, $1bn each from Brazil and Indonesia, and smaller sums from Portugal, the Netherlands and other countries.

The money is desperately needed to stave off the rapidly growing danger that the world’s biggest tropical forest will decline beyond a point of no return, after which it will be condemned to desiccate into a savannah and lose much of its globally important functions of climate stabilisation, water transport and habitat provision.

Senior scientists have warned that this is already happening in wide areas of the Amazon, particularly in the states of Matto Grosso, where there has been a rapid expansion of soy plantations, and Pará, where the primary cause of destruction is the beef industry. The weakening of the forest has also been accelerated by fire (widely used for land clearance) and the contamination of rivers with mercury (which is used in gold mining).

Antonio Donato Nobre, an Earth system scientist who worked in the Amazon for 20 years, said the forest is already showing signs of breakdown. He said droughts are increasingly severe, temperatures in some cleared areas have increased by up to 7C and degradation is accelerating even as deforestation slows. This poses a global threat, he said, not only because of a reduced carbon sequestration capacity, but because a weaker rainforest means less cloud cover to reflect the sun’s heat back into space, which is potentially a greater warming threat than greenhouse gases.

Nobre said the first climate summit in the Amazon was an opportunity to put nature at the heart of climate solutions but could also be a disaster if leaders paid only lip service to the importance of the forest, while pushing ahead with destructive projects. “My main message is get serious,” he said. “The most successful enterprise on the planet is called life. We have in our hands a technology that is 4bn years old and has gone through multiple cycles of destruction and rebirth and refixing.”

Lula, however, relies on support from the agribusiness and mining sectors to maintain power. “Ruralista” politicians dominate Congress, control several ministries, and are pushing an aggressive extractivist agenda that runs counter to forest conservation. This lobby is now the driving force in Brazilian politics.

While Lula has vetoed some of its most radical plans to eradicate swathes of environmental licensing requirements, he has also appeared more than willing to support other elements of its agenda to carve up the Amazon and other biomes for the production of fossil fuels and monoculture crops.

Three weeks ago, his government approved drilling licences for oil and gas exploration at the Foz do Amazonas off the coast of the rainforest, a move that adds to the contamination risks facing the forest, increases the likelihood of vegetation destruction by related industries and runs contrary to advice from the International Energy Agency that it will be impossible to achieve the Paris agreement goals of limiting global heating unless countries completely halt new fossil fuel development.

Then there are the government’s plans to upgrade the BR-319 highway between Manaus and Porto Velho, which will put unprecedented pressure on the western regions of the Brazilian Amazon, which have – until now – been one of the last healthy regions of the forest.

Another large intact area is close to the north-west border with Venezuela, but this too is menaced by plans to permit industrial mining in the Yanomami Indigenous territory.

“We’re very worried,” said one of those in the region, Ehuana Yaira Yanomami, who has come to Belém to relay the fears of the women of her community. “We don’t want our people to suffer, we are very worried and that’s why we are speaking out, because illegal mining only brings suffering to our communities. We want to see our children healthy, without mud and without the fish being contaminated.”

Farther south, the government announced in late August it would “de-statise” the federal waterways of three major rivers – the Tapajós, Madeira and Tocantins – which is seen as a first step towards their privatisation and transformation into a “hydrovia” water transport route for soy shipped from Mato Grosso.

Lula, who cut his political teeth as a union negotiator, has tended to focus more on the social benefits that can come from increased investment in the Amazon, while skirting the far greater risks that the climate crisis poses to its human and non-human residents.

That was evident last week at a pre-Cop30 publicity tour of forest communities along the Tapajós river. At the Vista Alegre do Capixauã village of the Kumaruara people, the president said he was ready to stand up for those who protect the forests, and promised to improve local healthcare, education and housing. This was very much in keeping with one of Brazil’s declared objectives in the summit: to make social protection a foundation of resilience.

But during the parts of his visit open to the press, Lula did not make a single mention of the climate, even though this is a growing concern for local people – and a huge majority of the world’s population.

The head of a neighbouring village, Luis Antonio Bentes de Sousa, told the Guardian that much of the river dried up during last year’s record drought, leaving the communities here stranded and struggling to feed themselves. He said his vegetable garden shrivelled up, most of his fruit trees died and for the first time in his 70-year-life he was unable to grow manioc, the primary staple of the Amazon diet.

“It is getting hotter and drier,” he said. “I worry for my children and grandchildren.”

Others spoke of mass fish deaths due to the heat, contamination and low water levels, and expressed fears that this will become worse when the river they depend on is privatised and turned into a canal for soy barges.

These uncomfortable topics – and their politically difficult solutions – were not raised during the speeches until the very end of Lula’s visit when the environment minister, Marina Silva, asked for the microphone and reminded the president why they were in the Amazon this month. “Cop30 is a place for us to say that Brazil will do its part, eliminating deforestation. And the world needs to do its part, reducing emissions of coal, oil and gas. That is why I like it when, sir, you say it’s necessary to stop depending on fossil fuels.”

This was a reminder that in Belém, Lula – like many world leaders – will have a good forest angel on one shoulder and a fossil fuel demon on the other. The question is which will hold sway.

name: EPA
title: SEPA Update: Towards Net Zero - 7th November 2025 - LinkedIn
description:
Facing a changing climate This month, the global spotlight turns to the environment and our collective efforts to combat climate change as COP30 convenes in Brazil.
With climate change reshaping seasonal norms, resilience depends on acting early, making informed choices, and working together across communities.
And yes, it’s possible to face both flooding and water scarcity at the same time.
Engage with SEPA tools and guidance - You can access our water scarcity seasonal reports during the winter months, along with guidance to make informed decisions.
Find out more about: changes to the Regulations Growing through change - new climate resilience guidance for Scotland’s horticulture sector The horticulture sector is increasingly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.
text:
Facing a changing climate

This month, the global spotlight turns to the environment and our collective efforts to combat climate change as COP30 convenes in Brazil. A decade on from the landmark Paris Agreement, world leaders are gathering to assess progress and chart a path forward to limit and prepare for climate change.

Europe is now warming twice as fast as the global average and the consequences of extreme weather are already being felt, from prolonged periods of water scarcity to increasingly frequent storms and flooding.

Yet, as the latest IPPR poll highlights, the environment doesn’t exist in isolation. While over half of Scots still view climate action as vital to the nation’s future, pressing concerns such as the NHS, cost of living and inequality currently top the public agenda.

Now, more than ever before, it’s important to recognise that the environment is not only at the heart of our identity as a nation but also integral to our success and development. We’re committed to taking action and one of the ways we’re doing this is through the nationally recognised Carbon Literacy Project, a training initiative where we’re equipping colleagues with the knowledge and tools to embed climate-conscious decision-making into everything they do, both at work and at home.

To mark Climate Literacy Action Day, this year taking place to coincide with COP30, we’re hosting staff sessions and expanding accreditation so our people can integrate climate decision-making into all aspects of their roles.

Preparing for a winter of extremes

As we head into another unpredictable winter, the swing between drought and downpour is becoming a familiar pattern. Last winter, some areas were drenched with above-average rainfall, while others saw less than half their usual precipitation.

The message is clear, winter preparedness now means being ready for both water shortages and flooding. With climate change reshaping seasonal norms, resilience depends on acting early, making informed choices, and working together across communities.

And yes, it’s possible to face both flooding and water scarcity at the same time. When heavy rain hits dry ground, it runs off like water on concrete, flooding streets but barely touching river levels. It’s all about timing; scarcity builds slowly, while flooding hits fast.

Prepare and be aware of flooding this winter

As winter approaches, communities across Scotland face an increased risk of flooding brought on by heavy rainfall, saturated ground and extreme weather events.

Flooding can affect you. It might be where you live, or your regular travel routes. Being prepared is key to staying safe and minimising disruption. We’re urging you to take action now to be prepared this winter by taking these easy steps:

Check the Scottish Flood Forecast - This provides a three-day outlook that shows when and where flooding is expected.

Sign up to Floodline - Receive real-time Alerts and Warnings direct by text, phone call or email, allowing you to take action when flooding is expected.

Follow our social media channels - We provide information on predicted flooding in advance through Facebook and X.

Explore how to: Prepare for flooding

Why we need to prepare for water scarcity this winter

Winter is traditionally seen as a time of water abundance, but recent trends tell a different story. In 2024, Scotland experienced a notably dry winter, with many regions recording below-average rainfall. The situation continued into 2025 with record-breaking dry conditions. These repeated dry spells placed sustained pressure on our rivers, keeping them under strain throughout the year.

While rivers are naturally resilient to seasonal fluctuations, prolonged low flows disrupt ecological balance and slow recovery. Consecutive years of reduced flow increase the risk of long-term or even irreversible changes to river ecosystems.

As we enter the winter months, all of Scotland’s rivers have recovered, with all areas at Alert level or below, and all abstraction restrictions lifted across the country.

However, the situation is delicate. That’s why we’re encouraging businesses, especially in agriculture, food production and manufacturing to be ready by integrating climate resilience into their planning.

If you rely on large amounts of water for your business:

Assess your water use - You should review how much water you use and identify areas where consumption can be reduced or recycled.

Engage with SEPA tools and guidance - You can access our water scarcity seasonal reports during the winter months, along with guidance to make informed decisions.

Collaborate locally - Work with suppliers, local authorities and environmental groups to help share resources and strategies.

Stay informed: Keep up to date with the latest situation this winter

Additional tips for winter readiness

Beyond the risks of flooding and water scarcity, winter can bring a host of other challenges. To help you stay safe, whether you're at home or heading outdoors, our partners have practical guidance to navigate the season with confidence.

Ready Scotland offers free guidance and resources to stay safe and resilient. This includes:

Tips for the loss of utilities.

Developing an emergency kit for your home.

Supporting those in need.

Home Energy Scotland offers free, tailored support to help Scottish households stay warm and save money during winter. They provide personalised energy advice, helping you reduce energy use without sacrificing comfort.

Latest Scottish household waste statistics highlight progress

Scotland’s latest household waste statistics have revealed a modest rise in recycling rates for 2024. While 44.3% of household waste was successfully recycled, we know that more than half of what ends up in general waste bins, such as food scraps, paper, cardboard and plastics, could have been recycled.

The carbon impact of household waste in 2024 was 5.31 million tonnes of CO₂ equivalent, marking a 21.5% decrease since 2011. This reduction underscores the environmental benefits of recycling and waste minimisation, especially as Scotland moves toward its goal of a circular economy.

With research showing that over half of general bin contents could be recycled, small changes in household habits, like better sorting and reducing food waste, could significantly boost recycling rates and cut emissions. Every effort counts in supporting Scotland’s transition to a more sustainable future.

Find out more about: Scotland's household waste statistics 2024

Zero Waste Scotland’s Recycling Sorter is a convenient digital tool that can help you identify which items can be recycled and in which colour of bin. Tailored to each Scottish local authority, it makes it easier for everyone to recycle correctly and efficiently.

Explore: Find out more.

Are you a reprocessor and exporter of UK packaging waste?

Get support to fulfil your obligation to purchase Packaging Waste Recycling Notes (PRNs) or Packaging Waste Export Recycling Notes (PERNs) at an upcoming webinar.

The session, hosted by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra), will take place on Tuesday 11th November at 2:00PM and will cover:

An overview of the summary log.

Raising and issuing PRNs.

Onboarding to the digital service.

Get involved: Book your space

Celebration or contamination? What bonfire night means for air quality

Across the country this week, skies have been lit with fireworks and bonfires as communities gathered for a night of sparkle and celebration. But while we enjoyed the show, it’s worth remembering that these fiery festivities come with a few hidden extras, especially for the air we breathe.

As the bonfires blaze and fireworks bang, they release tiny particles into the air, such as soot (black carbon) and colourful metal compounds like lead, copper and barium. These are what give fireworks their dazzling colours and crackling sounds, but they also contribute to fine particulate pollution (PM2.5), which can hang around in the air and irritate our lungs.

In previous years, our air quality monitors have picked up noticeable spikes in PM2.5 across Scotland between 5p.m. and 9p.m, right when the celebrations are in full swing. The levels didn’t last long, but they’re usually some of the highest of the week, showing just how much one night of fun can impact the air around us.

Explore the impact our daily lives can have on local air quality by having a look at some data collected during a citizen science project in Stirlingshire. This includes data from Aberfoyle’s bonfire night celebrations.

The chemistry of firework colours

Take a look: View air quality in your area

Extending the life of our assets to support net zero

As part of our ongoing efforts to modernise and reshape our workspaces, we’ll soon be co-locating with Zero Waste Scotland and the Water Industry Commission for Scotland in Stirling city centre. This move supports our net zero ambitions by promoting more sustainable travel, collaborative working and efficient use of shared resources.

Clearing our existing Stirling workspace became a practical demonstration of sustainability in action. Faced with vacating the space, we collaborated to repurpose surplus furniture and IT equipment. Extending the life of our assets has reduced waste and redistributed resources to support colleagues and communities. This approach helped cut emissions, avoid unnecessary procurement, and showed how smarter use of public sector assets delivers real environmental and social value.

View our: Net Zero Strategy

A new era of environmental regulation

Water, waste management and industrial activities have now joined radioactive substances in being regulated under the Environmental Authorisations (Scotland) Regulations 2018 (EASR).

The changes introduce a streamlined environmental regulatory framework and marks a major change in how we authorise and regulate activities. This integrated approach is designed to ensure efficient, effective and consistent regulation while reducing and simplifying the regulatory burden for organisations and businesses.

Find out more about: changes to the Regulations

Growing through change - new climate resilience guidance for Scotland’s horticulture sector

The horticulture sector is increasingly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. From shifting rainfall patterns and rising temperatures, to more frequent extreme weather events, these changes pose significant risks to plant health, supply chains and day-to-day operations.

Through our regulatory expertise, environmental data and collaborative partnerships, we support growers, landscapers and suppliers in understanding and adapting to these evolving climate challenges.

To further strengthen the sector’s resilience, Adaptation Scotland and the Horticultural Trades Association have developed new guidance tailored to Scotland’s horticultural industry. This resource identifies the key climate risks and provides practical, actionable steps to help businesses prepare and adapt.

Whether you're a grower, landscaper or supplier, the guide offers strategies already being adopted across Scotland, such as diversifying crops, enhancing drainage systems and rethinking business models, to build long-term resilience and sustainability in the face of a changing climate.

name: Clean Energy
title: Trump Seeks to Speed Large Power Projects to Meet AI Demand - The Business Download |
description:
(Bloomberg) — The Trump administration is seeking to speed the development of power plants, power lines, and other energy projects that can help meet the mounting electricity demand from AI and manufacturing.
The initiative comes as projected energy demand growth is outpacing the existing electric grid, the Energy Department said on Thursday.
The agency said it is seeking to marshal its technical know-how and billions of dollars in financial support and is asking for assistance from state energy offices, public utilities and other others in identifying large-scale power and electricity grid projects.
The effort comes as the agency has warned of blackouts if coal-fired and natural gas power plants continue to close, amid rapidly expanding electricity demand.
The Trump administration has also moved aggressively to block solar and wind power projects on federal land waters.
text:
(Bloomberg) —

The Trump administration is seeking to speed the development of power plants, power lines, and other energy projects that can help meet the mounting electricity demand from AI and manufacturing.

The initiative comes as projected energy demand growth is outpacing the existing electric grid, the Energy Department said on Thursday. The agency said it is seeking to marshal its technical know-how and billions of dollars in financial support and is asking for assistance from state energy offices, public utilities and other others in identifying large-scale power and electricity grid projects.

The effort comes as the agency has warned of blackouts if coal-fired and natural gas power plants continue to close, amid rapidly expanding electricity demand. The Trump administration has also moved aggressively to block solar and wind power projects on federal land waters.

title: US energy secretary slams COP30 summit | The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette
authors: DEREK GATOPOULOS, THEODORA TONGAS and MAURICIO SAVARESE The Associated Press
description:
ATHENS, Greece -- U.S. Energy Secretary Chris Wright on Friday condemned the COP30 environmental summit as harmful and misguided, defying the global scientific consensus and concern by governments worldwide on climate change.
The U.S. will send no high-level officials to the COP30 climate summit in Brazil, the White House said Friday.
"President Trump told me he doesn't believe in green energy," Lula told reporters earlier this week.

text:
ATHENS, Greece -- U.S. Energy Secretary Chris Wright on Friday condemned the COP30 environmental summit as harmful and misguided, defying the global scientific consensus and concern by governments worldwide on climate change.

"It's essentially a hoax. It's not an honest organization looking to better human lives," Wright told The Associated Press at the close of a two-day business conference in Athens. He added that he might attend next year's summit "just to try to deliver some common sense."

Wright's comments came as world leaders gathering over 5,000 miles away, on the edge of the Amazon in Brazil, blasted U.S. President Donald Trump for his absence from the United Nations-sponsored discussions on climate change running through Nov. 21. His remarks echoed the U.S. administration's rejection of global climate agreements and Trump's prioritization of fossil fuels.

The U.S. will send no high-level officials to the COP30 climate summit in Brazil, the White House said Friday.

"President Trump will not jeopardize our country's economic and national security to pursue vague climate goals that are killing other countries," Taylor Rogers, a White House spokesperson, said in a statement.

Wright led a senior U.S. delegation to Athens for talks centered on boosting U.S. liquefied natural gas exports to eastern Europe and Ukraine. Among them were Interior secretary Doug Burgum, deputy secretaries and the new U.S. ambassador to Greece and close Trump ally, Kimberly Guilfoyle.

At the forum, top U.S. officials criticized European Union carbon reduction policies, arguing they undermine economic growth, democratic alliances, and global leadership in AI and energy innovation.

It was a stark contrast with the Brazilian city of Belem, where world leaders at COP30 issued urgent warnings about the accelerating pace of global warming, driven in large part by emissions from burning fossil fuels like oil, gas and coal. U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres said a "moral failure" to act would trigger rising hunger, displacement and environmental damage.

Backed by overwhelming scientific consensus, the U.N. reaffirmed that climate change is already underway, requiring urgent global action to prevent irreversible harm.

Latin American leaders attending COP30 in Belem took swipes at Trump for his stance on climate discussions.

"Today Mr. Trump is against humanity. His absence is proof of that," Colombia's President Gustavo Petro said in his speech on Thursday. "What should we do then? Leave him alone. Oblivion is the biggest punishment."

Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva struck a more moderate tone regarding Trump's absence, expressing hope that his U.S. counterpart would eventually change his mind.

"President Trump told me he doesn't believe in green energy," Lula told reporters earlier this week. "He will believe in it, because he'll realize that we don't have much of an alternative."

Trump wasn't the only one staying away; the summit was also notably absent of leaders from China and India. Together, these three nations are the world's largest emitters of greenhouse gases.

Wright, a former fossil fuel executive who has been a leading voice against efforts to fight climate change, defended Washington's stance, arguing that global gatherings should prioritize energy access, growth and technological advancement over what he described as fear-driven environmentalism.

"Gatherings of global leaders and businesses should be about humans ... not on the desire to scare children and grow government power," he told the AP in Athens. "They've lost the plot."

The Belem talks opened as the U.N. weather agency announced that 2025 was on track to be the second or third warmest year ever recorded. The concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which hit a record high last year, continued to rise in 2025, as did ocean heat and sea levels, the World Meteorological Organization reported Thursday.

Trump has reversed Biden's focus on slowing climate change to pursue what the Republican calls U.S. "energy dominance" in the global market. At the U.N. General Assembly in September, he called climate change "the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world."

At the start of his second term, Trump again withdrew the U.S. from the 2015 Paris climate agreement, while the Environmental Protection Agency has announced a series of actions to roll back landmark regulations.

Information for this article was contributed by Matthew Daly of The Associated Press.

name: Clean Energy
title: Why we should embrace a fossil fuel-free future - The Grand Junction Daily Sentinel
description:
It’s true that manufacturing EVs and solar panels currently generates carbon emissions.
The emissions from a gasoline car are not limited to what comes out of the tailpipe.
There is no practical pathway to “carbon-free” with a gasoline car.
A gasoline car getting 20 mpg will consume 500 gallons of gasoline to go that far.
Transitioning to a fossil fuel-free economy isn’t just about fighting climate change, it’s about creating a healthier, more affordable, sustainable and stable future.
text:
It’s true that manufacturing EVs and solar panels currently generates carbon emissions. However, when we look at the full lifecycle — “cradle to grave” — EVs produce significantly less CO2 than gasoline-powered cars. The emissions from a gasoline car are not limited to what comes out of the tailpipe. We must consider the entire “well to wheels” process: drilling for oil, transporting crude, refining it, shipping gasoline to stations, and finally burning it in engines that are only about 30% efficient (70% turned into heat and wasted). Each step adds pollution and greenhouse gases to our environment. This goes on for the entire life of the gasoline-powered car. There is no practical pathway to “carbon-free” with a gasoline car.

For solar panels, emissions are concentrated during manufacturing (mining, refining, panel production). Average carbon payback period is one to four years, meaning they offset their production emissions within that time. After payback, they generate electricity with near-zero emissions for 25-30 years. Another great advantage of rooftop solar is a locked-in price for each and every kilowatt-hour. No worries about inflation, AI and crypto raising the cost of electricity. You can go solar with either a zero-cost power purchase agreement from a company like Atlasta Solar or by purchasing solar panels outright at a reduced cost through a co-op like Solar United Neighbors.

Back to EVs; even though tailpipe emissions from gasoline-powered vehicles are often invisible, they contain a potent mix of harmful pollutants that can make us sick. These include carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, fine particulates, and unburned hydrocarbons like benzene and formaldehyde — both known carcinogens. Despite their invisibility, these compounds contribute to respiratory problems, cardiovascular disease, and long-term environmental damage, silently affecting the air we breathe and the health of our communities. You also subject yourself to a cocktail of chemicals every time you pump gas. Some benign, some not so much. Let’s not forget that medicine itself is a major consumer of single-use plastics, so anything that lowers our need for health care also helps reduce waste, pollution and energy consumption.

Financially, EVs are much cheaper to operate. The lifetime cost of driving on electricity is far lower than buying gasoline, especially as global instability affects oil prices. Routine maintenance is also less expensive, since EVs have fewer moving parts and don’t require oil changes. Consider the cost of driving 10,000 miles. A gasoline car getting 20 mpg will consume 500 gallons of gasoline to go that far. Assuming a low price of $5 per gallon this would take $2,500 out of your pocket. An EV consuming 30 kWhs to drive 100 miles would consume 3,000 kWhs. At offpeak Xcel rates of 8.5 cents per kWh, this would take $255 out of your pocket. Less if you have rooftop solar. Driving a gas car could easily have fuel costs more than 10 times as much as an EV charged at home. More than 80% of EV charging is done at home. We charge 100% at home. But what the heck! You don’t mind working part time for the oil oligarchs, do you.

Envision an electrified future where all manufacturing and transportation does not create carbon dioxide and all people are freed from the tyranny of oil. If a war breaks out in the Middle East, gasoline could easily hit $10 per gallon or higher and there’s nothing you can do about it. Meanwhile, the cost of driving electric will be virtually unchanged, especially if you make your own ‘fuel’ on your roof. Your choice.

Transitioning to a fossil fuel-free economy isn’t just about fighting climate change, it’s about creating a healthier, more affordable, sustainable and stable future. Investing in clean energy isn’t just affordable — it’s the key to securing America’s prosperity and leadership for generations to come.

Tom Phillips is a chemical engineer with more than 30 years of experience in the international oil business, mainly in the manufacture of gasoline, diesel and jet fuel. He has lived in the Grand Valley for 35 years.

title: China's Rare Earth Export Controls Transform Global Supply Chains - Discovery Alert

Navigating the Future of Rare Earth Markets China's rare earth export controls have fundamentally transformed global supply chain assumptions and strategic planning requirements across critical technology sectors.
text:
Understanding Beijing's Strategic Mineral Restrictions

China's rare earth export controls represent a sophisticated regulatory framework that transforms critical minerals from market commodities into strategic diplomatic leverage. The licensing mechanism, administered through China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), establishes government oversight over materials essential to modern technology manufacturing.

The Foundation of Modern Export Control Policy

The current licensing system emerged from decades of policy evolution, moving from open market competition toward strategic resource management. MOFCOM's authority stems from China's foreign trade law framework, enabling rapid implementation of export restrictions across defined material categories. As of November 2025, the ministry had issued 62 regulatory announcements pertaining to export controls, with specific announcements suspended until November 2026 according to official statements.

Furthermore, the distinction between temporary suspensions and permanent policy changes proves critical for understanding Beijing's approach. The November 7, 2025 announcement suspended Announcements 55, 56, 57, 58, 61, and 62 until November 10, 2026, creating a precise one-year pause with automatic reinstatement provisions. This structure maintains regulatory pressure while providing diplomatic flexibility.

Critical Materials Under Regulatory Oversight

China's export control framework targets both raw materials and processing equipment across the rare earth supply chain. Heavy rare earth elements including dysprosium and terbium face licensing requirements due to their irreplaceable role in high-temperature magnetic applications. These materials enable electric vehicle motors and wind turbine generators to maintain performance under thermal stress conditions.

Light rare earth elements such as neodymium and praseodymium also require export licenses, affecting the foundation of permanent magnet production globally. Consequently, the regulatory scope extends beyond raw materials to include processing equipment, creating vertical control across multiple supply chain stages. This comprehensive approach prevents circumvention through alternative processing routes.

Downstream products affected by the controls include finished magnets, catalysts, and technology components incorporating rare earth materials. The licensing requirements create compounding restrictions as materials progress through manufacturing stages, amplifying supply chain complexity for international manufacturers.

How China's 2025 Export Controls Actually Unfolded

Timeline of Regulatory Tightening and Market Response

The implementation of China's rare earth export controls during 2025 followed a calculated escalation pattern, creating maximum market disruption while maintaining policy flexibility. Each phase introduced new restrictions while building upon existing regulatory infrastructure alongside emerging critical minerals strategy initiatives.

April 2025: The Initial Shock Wave

Seven rare earth elements were placed under licensing requirements in April 2025, triggering immediate supply chain disruptions across critical technology sectors. Chinese magnet exports experienced a 50% decline within the first month as exporters struggled to navigate new permit requirements according to Reuters reporting.

The automotive sector faced particularly acute pressure, with portions of the global auto industry approaching shutdown conditions by May 2025 due to magnet shortages. This three-to-four week lag between regulatory implementation and critical supply failure demonstrated the fragility of just-in-time manufacturing systems dependent on Chinese rare earth materials.

Additionally, export license application backlogs developed rapidly, with over 2,000 applications from European Union companies alone by November 2025. The approval process proved complex and time-consuming, requiring multi-hundred page documentation packages and end-use justifications submitted to multiple Chinese government agencies simultaneously.

Market reactions were swift and substantial. Praseodymium-neodymium oxide prices surged approximately 40% year-to-date through November 2025, with an additional 14% weekly spike occurring during peak supply uncertainty. These price movements demonstrated the direct correlation between regulatory announcements and rare earth commodity valuations.

October 2025: Extraterritorial Expansion

China expanded its export control scope in October 2025, adding five additional rare earth elements to the controlled substances list. More significantly, Beijing introduced a foreign direct product rule for rare earth materials, establishing a 50% ownership threshold for export license determinations.

This extraterritorial provision extended compliance requirements beyond Chinese borders to international companies with partial Chinese ownership or significant supply chain involvement. However, the 50% threshold created immediate complications for joint ventures and companies with Chinese investment partners, forcing restructuring of ownership arrangements to maintain material access.

The October measures also targeted rare earth processing equipment separately from raw materials, suggesting a deliberate strategy to control both primary production inputs and intermediate processing capabilities. This vertical approach created multiple control points across the supply chain rather than focusing solely on finished goods.

November 2025: The Misunderstood "Rollback"

The November 7, 2025 MOFCOM announcement created significant confusion in Western media and markets, with many characterising the move as a policy rollback rather than a temporary suspension. The official statement suspended specific announcements until November 10, 2026, creating a precise one-year window with automatic reinstatement provisions.

Crucially, the core licensing infrastructure remained fully operational despite the suspension of select October announcements. Export license applications continued requiring extensive documentation and multi-agency approval processes, maintaining bureaucratic friction regardless of suspended announcement numbers.

Western media mischaracterisation of the announcement as effectively ending rare earth controls glossed over the technical distinction between suspending specific measures and eliminating the licensing requirement framework entirely. The White House description of the moves proved overly optimistic compared to the actual policy language and implementation reality according to analysis by the Centre for Strategic and International Studies.

Bureaucratic delays persisted despite suspension headlines, with approval rates varying significantly based on end-use applications. Defense-related applications continued experiencing rejection rates approaching 80%, while commercial applications achieved approximately 50% approval rates through November 2025.

China's Strategic Dominance in Rare Earth Markets

Market Control Statistics and Geopolitical Leverage

China's position in global rare earth markets extends far beyond simple production statistics, creating a comprehensive dominance structure that spans extraction, processing, and manufacturing capabilities. This vertical integration provides Beijing with multiple leverage points across critical technology supply chains.

Production and Processing Monopoly

China controls approximately 60% of global rare earth extraction operations, but this figure understates the true extent of strategic dominance. More critically, China processes 85-90% of refined rare earth oxides globally, creating an essential chokepoint regardless of where initial mining occurs.

The processing monopoly proves particularly significant because rare earth ores require complex chemical separation and purification procedures before use in technology applications. Alternative mining operations outside China often depend on Chinese processing facilities to create usable materials, maintaining Beijing's leverage even over non-Chinese mineral sources.

Magnet manufacturing represents China's most concentrated advantage, with approximately 90% of high-performance permanent magnets produced within Chinese facilities. This downstream integration ensures that even if alternative rare earth sources develop, the critical manufacturing capacity remains under Chinese control.

Economic Impact Across Critical Industries

The scope of China's rare earth influence extends across multiple technology sectors with varying dependency levels and supply risk profiles:

Sector Dependency Level Key Applications Supply Risk Electric Vehicles Critical Motor magnets, batteries High Wind Energy Essential Generator magnets High Defense Systems Strategic Guidance systems, electronics Critical Consumer Electronics Moderate Speakers, hard drives Medium

Electric vehicle manufacturers face critical dependency on Chinese rare earth supplies for motor magnet production, with no viable short-term alternatives for high-performance applications. Wind energy sector dependency proves essential for generator efficiency, while defence systems require strategic materials for guidance and electronic systems.

Chokepoint Analysis for Global Supply Chains

Single points of failure characterise the rare earth supply chain, with Chinese processing capacity representing the most significant vulnerability. Lead times have extended from typical weeks to months as licensing requirements create additional delays and uncertainty.

Price volatility demonstrates direct correlation with Chinese regulatory announcements, as evidenced by the 40% year-to-date increase in praseodymium-neodymium oxide prices through November 2025. This price sensitivity reflects the lack of alternative suppliers capable of meeting global demand at scale.

Alternative supplier capacity gaps remain substantial, with non-Chinese sources unable to replace Chinese production volumes within reasonable timeframes. Timeline projections for meaningful supply chain diversification extend 5-10 years minimum for most critical applications, maintaining Chinese leverage throughout the transition period.

Heavy Rare Earth Elements: Maximum Vulnerability

Strategic Importance of Dysprosium and Terbium

Heavy rare earth elements occupy a unique position in the critical materials landscape due to their irreplaceable performance characteristics and extreme geographic concentration. Unlike light rare earth elements where some substitution pathways exist, dysprosium and terbium provide essential properties for high-temperature applications with no current alternatives.

High-Temperature Performance Requirements

Motor efficiency in electric vehicles depends on dysprosium addition to prevent thermal demagnetisation above specific temperature thresholds. High-performance and military vehicle applications require mission-critical reliability across wide temperature ranges, making dysprosium essential for maintaining magnetic properties under extreme thermal stress.

Wind turbine generator reliability in harsh environments demands terbium addition to maintain magnetic stability during thermal cycling conditions created by intermittent power generation and mechanical stress. Modern permanent magnet generators cannot achieve required efficiency and durability specifications without heavy rare earth enhancement.

Military applications requiring temperature stability in guidance systems and electronics represent strategic end-uses where performance degradation poses mission-critical risks. These defence applications experience rejection rates approaching 80% for Chinese export license applications, demonstrating Beijing's strategic prioritisation of supply restrictions to military sectors.

Geographic Concentration Risks

Southern China clay deposits serve as the primary global source for heavy rare earth elements, creating extreme geographic concentration risk. These deposits, located primarily in ionic clay formations, contain the highest concentrations of dysprosium and terbium accessible through current extraction technologies.

Myanmar border region instability affects supply routes and alternative sourcing options, compounding the geographic concentration problem. Political tensions and infrastructure limitations in border areas create additional supply chain vulnerabilities beyond Chinese regulatory controls.

Furthermore, limited viable alternative deposits outside Chinese territorial control constrain diversification efforts. While heavy rare earth elements exist in other global locations, the concentrations and extraction economics prove significantly less favourable than Chinese sources, limiting practical substitution potential.

Processing technology barriers prevent non-Chinese producers from achieving equivalent separation and purification capabilities. The complex chemistry required for heavy rare earth processing remains concentrated within Chinese facilities, creating additional dependency beyond raw material extraction.

Industry Adaptation Strategies and Engineering Solutions

HREE-Free Magnet Innovations

Engineering teams across multiple industries have accelerated development of heavy rare earth-free solutions in response to supply chain uncertainties. These innovations focus on achieving equivalent performance through design modifications and alternative material compositions rather than depending on scarce dysprosium and terbium supplies.

Engineering Solutions and Supply Chain Diversification

N45SH and N48SH magnet grades have achieved high performance benchmarks entirely without dysprosium addition, representing significant technological progress in HREE-free manufacturing. The N48SH grade reportedly under development promises even higher performance specifications while maintaining independence from heavy rare earth supplies.

Laminated magnet designs reduce heat-related demagnetisation through improved thermal management, lessening dependency on dysprosium's high-temperature properties. These segmented architectures distribute thermal stress more effectively, enabling HREE-free magnets to achieve performance levels previously requiring heavy rare earth enhancement.

Grain boundary diffusion techniques enhance coercivity in light rare earth magnets, providing alternative pathways to high-temperature performance. Advanced processing methods enable optimisation of magnetic properties without requiring scarce heavy rare earth additions.

In addition, cerium-based alloy research explores lighter rare earth substitutes for traditional heavy rare earth applications. These investigations focus on abundant light rare earth elements that could replace dysprosium and terbium in specific applications while maintaining required performance characteristics.

Design Engineering Workarounds

Innovation Spotlight: Automotive engineers are implementing segmented magnet architectures and advanced cooling systems to maintain motor performance while reducing dependency on temperature-resistant heavy rare earths.

Motor design modifications include larger magnet volumes and improved cooling systems to achieve equivalent performance without heavy rare earth enhancement. These engineering approaches trade material scarcity for design complexity, enabling continued production despite supply constraints.

Laminated stacks and advanced motor controls provide additional pathways for maintaining efficiency while reducing rare earth dependency. These system-level solutions optimise overall performance through intelligent design rather than relying solely on material properties.

Alternative Supply Chain Development

Government investment in domestic rare earth capacity has accelerated significantly during 2025, with the US Department of Defense allocating $400 million toward domestic production capabilities. This represents substantial federal commitment to supply chain resilience alongside the executive order on minerals initiatives, though capacity development timelines extend multiple years.

Australian rare earth projects are ramping production capacity to provide alternatives to Chinese sources, though processing capabilities remain limited. Projects including Lynas Corporation and emerging producers aim to establish integrated supply chains independent of Chinese processing infrastructure.

Canadian processing facilities target 2026-2027 operational dates, representing potential diversification opportunities for North American manufacturers. These developments focus on establishing domestic processing capabilities rather than depending on Chinese separation and purification facilities.

European Union critical materials stockpiling initiatives aim to create strategic reserves for supply disruption scenarios. These government-led programmes prioritise building buffer inventories of essential materials while longer-term diversification efforts develop capacity.

Export License Requirements: Practical Business Impact

Compliance Challenges and Market Friction

The licensing requirement framework creates substantial operational complexity for global manufacturers dependent on Chinese rare earth supplies. Application processes involve extensive documentation, multi-agency coordination, and unpredictable approval timelines that fundamentally alter supply chain planning approaches.

Application Process Complexity

Multi-hundred page documentation requirements characterise export license applications, demanding detailed technical specifications, end-use justifications, and supply chain transparency. Companies must provide comprehensive product descriptions, importing entity verification, and strategic use attestations across multiple Chinese government agencies simultaneously.

Processing timeframes extend 3-6 months minimum for standard applications, with defence-related applications experiencing significantly longer delays or outright rejections. The approval process involves coordination between MOFCOM, customs authorities, and security agencies, creating multiple points where applications may encounter delays or denials.

End-use justification requirements force companies to provide detailed explanations of intended applications, creating transparency demands that may compromise competitive information. Manufacturers must balance regulatory compliance with protection of proprietary product development information.

Rejection rates for defence-related applications approach 80%, creating effective embargoes on Chinese rare earth supplies for military applications. This selective approval process enables China to maintain commercial relationships while restricting strategic end-uses.

Operational Impact on Global Manufacturers

Just-in-time inventory models have become obsolete for manufacturers dependent on Chinese rare earth supplies, forcing fundamental changes to working capital and storage requirements. Companies have shifted toward maintaining substantial buffer inventories to accommodate licensing delays and approval uncertainties.

Safety stock requirements have increased 300-500% compared to pre-control inventory levels, representing substantial working capital impacts for affected manufacturers. This inventory expansion reflects the need to maintain production continuity despite unpredictable supply chain disruptions.

Supplier qualification processes now extend beyond technical specifications to include regulatory compliance capabilities and licensing track records. Manufacturers must evaluate suppliers based on their ability to navigate Chinese export control requirements successfully rather than focusing solely on cost and quality metrics.

Contract terms increasingly incorporate regulatory change clauses to address the possibility of sudden policy modifications. These provisions attempt to allocate risk between parties for scenarios involving unexpected export control modifications or licensing delays.

Financial Implications for Supply Chain Planning

Price premiums for non-Chinese rare earth sources range 15-25% above Chinese rates, reflecting scarcity value and alternative supplier capacity constraints. These premiums represent structural cost increases that affect manufacturing economics across rare earth-dependent industries.

Working capital increases result from extended lead times and higher inventory requirements, creating financing pressures for manufacturers adapting to new supply chain realities. Companies must secure additional financing to accommodate longer cash conversion cycles and higher safety stock levels.

However, currency hedging complexity increases with multi-jurisdiction sourcing strategies designed to reduce Chinese dependency. Manufacturers must manage foreign exchange exposure across multiple currencies and longer time horizons than traditional supply arrangements required.

Insurance costs for supply chain disruption coverage have risen substantially as insurers recognise the systemic risks created by rare earth export controls. Premium increases reflect the concentrated nature of rare earth supply chains and the potential for sudden regulatory changes.

Diversification Progress and Remaining Vulnerabilities

Production Capacity Development Outside China

Global efforts to reduce dependence on Chinese rare earth supplies have accelerated significantly, though capacity development timelines extend multiple years and involve substantial capital requirements. Current progress demonstrates both promise and limitations in achieving supply chain independence, particularly given the broader defense materials strategy considerations.

Progress Assessment and Remaining Vulnerabilities

Region Current Capacity 2027 Projections Key Projects Australia 15% of global 25% of global Lynas, Iluka Resources North America 5% of global 12% of global MP Materials, Ucore Europe 2% of global 8% of global REE processing partnerships

Australian production capacity represents the most advanced alternative to Chinese sources, with Lynas Corporation operating integrated mining and processing facilities. However, downstream processing for speciality applications remains limited compared to Chinese capabilities, constraining substitution potential for high-performance applications.

North American capacity development focuses on domestic supply chain security, with MP Materials expanding production at Mountain Pass and other companies developing processing capabilities. Government support through defence department contracts provides revenue certainty for capacity investment decisions.

European initiatives emphasise processing partnerships and strategic material stockpiling rather than domestic mining operations. The European Union's critical materials strategy prioritises reducing processing dependence through technology partnerships and supply chain diversification agreements.

Technology Transfer and Processing Capabilities

Separation technology licensing agreements with Chinese firms create potential vulnerabilities in diversification strategies, as technology access depends on maintaining positive relationships with Chinese partners. These arrangements may face restrictions during periods of heightened geopolitical tensions.

Independent processing development timelines require 5-7 years minimum to achieve commercial-scale operations, reflecting the technical complexity of rare earth separation and purification processes. Environmental permitting challenges in Western jurisdictions add additional time and uncertainty to project development schedules.

Capital requirements exceeding $1 billion characterise integrated rare earth processing facilities capable of competing with Chinese operations. These substantial investment thresholds limit the number of viable projects and extend development timelines as companies secure financing.

Environmental compliance costs in developed countries create structural disadvantages compared to Chinese operations, affecting long-term competitiveness of alternative suppliers. Regulatory requirements for waste management and environmental protection add operational costs that must be recovered through higher prices.

Market Reality Check on Supply Security

Non-Chinese capacity remains insufficient for complete substitution through 2030, maintaining structural dependence on Chinese supplies for most applications. Even aggressive capacity development scenarios leave significant supply gaps that require continued Chinese sourcing for global demand fulfilment.

Quality specifications for premium applications often require Chinese processing capabilities, limiting substitution potential even when alternative raw materials become available. The precision and consistency achieved by Chinese processing facilities proves difficult to replicate in new operations.

Cost competitiveness gaps persist despite geopolitical risk premiums, as Chinese operations benefit from scale economies and integrated supply chains. Alternative suppliers must achieve substantial scale before achieving cost parity with Chinese producers, extending the timeline for meaningful competition.

Strategic stockpile adequacy provides only 3-6 months maximum buffer for most countries, insufficient to weather extended supply disruptions or allow time for alternative capacity development. Government reserves focus on emergency preparedness rather than long-term supply independence.

Strategic Planning for Regulatory Uncertainty

Investment Implications and Long-term Outlook

The rare earth export control environment has fundamentally altered investment and strategic planning assumptions across technology sectors. Regulatory volatility represents the new baseline condition rather than temporary disruption, requiring adaptive strategies that accommodate ongoing uncertainty, particularly given recent developments in US minerals deal negotiations.

Policy Volatility as the New Normal

Export control frameworks enable rapid implementation of new restrictions without extended notification periods, creating permanent uncertainty for supply chain planning. The November 2025 suspension demonstrates how quickly policy conditions can change while maintaining underlying control infrastructure.

Suspension agreements remain subject to geopolitical relationship changes, with automatic reinstatement provisions ensuring that controls can resume without new regulatory processes. This structure maintains compliance pressure even during periods of apparent policy relaxation.

License approval rates correlate directly with diplomatic tensions between China and importing countries, creating additional unpredictability beyond technical application requirements. Companies must monitor geopolitical relationships as carefully as supply chain logistics when planning rare earth sourcing strategies.

Regulatory arbitrage opportunities continue diminishing over time as China expands control scope and international coordination increases. The extraterritorial provisions introduced in October 2025 demonstrate Beijing's willingness to extend controls beyond direct bilateral relationships.

Investment Implications for Critical Materials Sector

Rare earth mining equities have experienced 40-60% volatility ranges during 2025, reflecting investor uncertainty regarding supply chain developments and regulatory changes. Price movements correlate strongly with policy announcements rather than fundamental supply and demand factors.

Processing technology companies command premium valuations as investors recognise the strategic value of separation and purification capabilities. Companies with proven rare earth processing expertise benefit from scarcity value as alternatives to Chinese facilities gain importance.

Recycling and urban mining ventures attract strategic investment as manufacturers seek to reduce dependence on primary rare earth sources. These circular economy approaches offer potential supply chain independence while addressing environmental sustainability concerns.

Defence contractors prioritise supply chain resilience over cost optimisation, creating premium markets for non-Chinese rare earth sources. Government procurement preferences for domestic or allied suppliers support higher pricing for secure supply arrangements.

Long-term Strategic Considerations

Market Reality: While engineering innovations and alternative suppliers are developing rapidly, complete independence from Chinese rare earth supply chains remains 5-10 years away for most critical applications, making adaptive strategies more valuable than absolute solutions.

Technology evolution may reduce rare earth dependency over the long term through materials science advances and design optimisation. However, current applications in electric vehicles, wind energy, and defence systems continue requiring rare earth materials with no immediate substitutes available.

Geopolitical relationships will significantly influence the pace and direction of supply chain diversification efforts. Improved diplomatic relationships could reduce incentives for alternative supplier development, while continued tensions would accelerate diversification investments.

Economic competitiveness of alternative sources depends on achieving sufficient scale to compete with Chinese cost structures. Success requires sustained investment and market support during extended development periods when alternative suppliers operate at cost disadvantages.

Strategic stockpiling provides short-term supply security but cannot replace the need for sustainable long-term supply chain development. Government reserves serve emergency preparedness functions while industry develops alternative capacity and supply arrangements.

Navigating the Future of Rare Earth Markets

China's rare earth export controls have fundamentally transformed global supply chain assumptions and strategic planning requirements across critical technology sectors. The November 2025 suspension of select export control announcements demonstrates regulatory flexibility while maintaining structural control over essential materials according to analysis by the International Energy Agency.

The distinction between temporary policy adjustments and permanent strategic reversals proves critical for business planning and investment decisions. Beijing's approach maintains comprehensive leverage through processing capacity dominance and vertical supply chain integration regardless of specific regulatory announcements.

Industry adaptation through engineering innovation and alternative supplier development represents the most promising pathway toward supply chain resilience. HREE-free magnet technologies and diversified processing capacity reduce dependency on Chinese supplies while maintaining performance requirements.

However, complete independence from Chinese rare earth supply chains remains 5-10 years away for most critical applications, requiring adaptive strategies that accommodate ongoing regulatory uncertainty. Success depends on balancing immediate supply needs with long-term diversification investments while managing the financial and operational impacts of extended transition timelines.

Disclaimer: This analysis contains forward-looking statements regarding rare earth market developments, regulatory changes, and technology evolution. Actual outcomes may differ significantly from projections due to geopolitical, economic, and technological factors. Investors should conduct independent research and consider professional advice before making investment decisions based on this information.

text:
(The Hill) – In recent weeks, automakers and other companies in the vehicle space are pulling back their investments in electric vehicles (EVs), including laying off workers in multiple states.

The moves come in the wake of Republicans’ “big, beautiful bill,” which repealed incentives for consumers to buy electric cars.

GM in particular is set to lay off 1,200 workers from its Detroit plant and another 550 from its Ultium Cells plant in Ohio.

Meanwhile, another 850 are being temporarily laid off from the Ohio Ultium Cells plant, and 710 will be temporarily let go from an Ultium factory in Tennessee.

While those layoffs were the largest that were recently announced, they’re not the only ones.

Last month, EV-maker Rivian told staff it would let go of about 4.5 percent of its workforce. Reuters reported that this represents more than 600 jobs.

“With the changing operating backdrop, we had to rethink how we are scaling our go-to-market functions,” Rivian CEO RJ Scaringe said in a note to staff seen by The Hill.

Meanwhile, Freudenberg e-Power Systems said this week that it would close two EV battery facilities in Michigan, laying off 324 workers.

“We have reached this difficult decision due to the decrease in demand for heavy-duty electric and hybrid electric vehicles in North America,” the company said in a statement.

The moves come after this year’s “big, beautiful bill” eliminated a tax credit for consumers that brought down EV prices by up to $7,500.

The credit expired at the end of September.

GM, whose spokespeople did not immediately respond to The Hill’s request for comment, cited in a recent note to investors government policies and specifically the end of incentives as part of a need to reassess its electric vehicle strategy.

“With the evolving regulatory framework and the end of federal consumer incentives, it is now clear that near-term EV adoption will be lower than planned,” said the letter from CEO Mary Barra last month ahead of the layoff announcement.

“That is why we are reassessing our EV capacity and manufacturing footprint. The work, which is ongoing, resulted in a special charge in the third quarter, and we expect future charges,” Barra said.

Meanwhile, Shawn Fain, president of the United Autoworkers union, criticized both the company and the government.

“Last week, GM raised its expected annual profits to $13 billion dollars. This week, they announced layoffs…. The company continues to post billions in profits every year,” he said.

“Going into negotiations, we knew — and the company knew — that the electric vehicle transition was going to be volatile. The cutting of federal subsidies for EVs has only made that volatility worse,” he added.

Stephanie Valdez Streaty, director of industry insights at Cox Automotive, told The Hill that federal policies, especially the end of the tax credits, are a major factor in the layoffs.

“It’s been significant in slowing EV demand,” Valdez Streaty said.

However, she also noted other factors impacting automakers more generally that may be playing a role.

“You also have tariffs that are going on. You have chip shortages…there’s [an] aluminum fire that hurt production…there’s all these different things that are going on that are just amplifying or magnifying the navigation manufacturers have to do in terms of production,” she said.

Mike Madowitz, principal economist at the Roosevelt Institute, said that while some of these layoffs could be transferred to other jobs, including equivalent jobs related to gas-powered cars, they’re coming at a tough time for manufacturing more broadly.

“It’s pretty hard to not notice that manufacturing employment has been falling basically ever since we had tariffs announced,” Madowitz said.

“If you’re making the multi-decade commitments that you do when you’re investing in auto and battery plants, you have to think harder about your ability to export stuff from America,” he added.
